newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: New violence erupts in French Guiana.
newsitem.headline: New violence erupts in French Guiana.

text.p: New violence erupted in French Guiana on Monday night as police and demonstrators clashed in the capital, Cayenne, after a judicial procedure that kept an independence leader in pre-trial detention, witnesses said.
Paramilitary riot police used tear gas to disperse several hundred demonstrators who had camped out in front of the central courthouse for several hours.
The acrid smell of tear gas penetrated into homes of nearby residents and riot police were patrolling the city and guarding strategic locations.
Local state-owned radio said demonstrators attempted to set fire to the town's central police station and electricity was cut in certain sections.
There were no immediate reports of injuries.

The violence was triggered by the arrest last month of Jean-Victor Castor, a leading member of French Guiana's independence movement. He is accused of violence against a policeman during a wave of riots in April that left nine police injured, eight by gunfire.

April's riots were sparked by the arrest of 10 other members of the independence movement for an attack on the residence of the French territory's state prosecutor during a wave of riots in November 1996.
The violence has shattered French Guiana's tranquil facade and laid bare economic, political and social woes.
French Guiana is the only non-indpendent territory on the mainland of the Western Hemisphere.
It lags behind mainland France in housing, education and health care. Official unemployment of the population of 150,000 exceeds 25 percent and the economy is heavily dependent on French subsidies.
